story: Your voice assistant wakes you up for the day. She tells you today’s weather, your schedule for the day, and starts playing music for you.
Which voice assistant do you have?

risks: Google Home is always listening to you, not just when you ask it something because it needs to be listening for the wake word (for instance, “Ok Google”) (source)
Google keeps a record of all your interactions with any of its products (including Google Home) for targeted advertising (source)
recs: Regularly review and delete your voice recordings (instructions)
Mute the mic using the physical switch when not using it (source)

risks: Alexa remembers all of the interactions you’ve had with her and has even accidentally sent over 1700 voice files to a stranger who didn’t even have an Alexa-enabled device (source)
Alexa creates transcripts and voice recordings of your conversations, and these are manually reviewed by Amazon employees to improve Alexa’s listening capabilities (source)
Alexa skills are vulnerable to hackers listening in on your conversations without you knowing (source)
recs: Regularly review and delete your recordings (source)
Opt-out of sending your data to Amazon to improve Alexa’s listening capabilities (source)

story: You are now headed to school.
Do you take public transit or use a ride sharing service like Uber?

risks: PRESTO keeps a record of information related to your financial transactions. This includes your credit card number and bank information (source)
All the locations you tap your card at are stored (source)
recs: The best way to avoid these risks is to use public transit with cash rather than with a Presto card (which means that you’d have to trade convenience for privacy)

risks: Uber collects your geolocation data (e.g. where you are, where you go, and, sometimes, even how long you there for) (source)
If you link Uber to other social medias, voice assistants, or other apps, it can access those external data and use them for their other products (i.e. Uber Eats) (source)
In 2015, Uber suffered a data breach that exposed the personal information of 50,000 drivers (source)
recs: Turn off location services and type in the pick up address and drop off address manually
The best way to avoid these risks is to not use the app. However, be aware that by using this app, you are potentially putting your privacy at risk.

story: You finish all your tasks for the day and you decide to slack off a little. You pull out your phone and go on to Instagram to see what everyone is up to.
Are you logging in with a separate Instagram account or other social media accounts, such as Facebook, Apple ID?

options.optionText: Log in with a separate IG account
risks: Instagram collects your geolocation data. For example, adding geotags to your photos will allow Instagram to know where you spend your time and display relevant ad (source)
Instagram can access other social media accounts and your private contact list (source)
User information can be transferred to a third part (source)
There has been a vulnerability on Instagram, which would let an attacker access account details and phone numbers (source)
recs: Turn off location services and real time alert
Do not use other social media accounts for Instagram login
Make your profile private
Delete the contacts that you may have uploaded to Instagram from your phone

options.optionText: Log in via another social media account
risks: Instagram collects your geolocation data. For example, adding geotags to your photos will allow Instagram to know where you spend your time and display relevant ads (source)
The new DM feature alerts real-timeily others to exactly what you’re doing on the app and when you’re doing it (source)
User information can be transferred to a third party (source)
There has been a vulnerability of Instagram, which would let an attacker access account details and phone numbers (source)
recs: Turn off location services and real time alert
Make your profile private

story: Immediately, you see that your friend has posted a photo of them celebrating their birthday with their family.
Do you like and comment on their post?

risks: Instagram collects behavioural data through cookies, analytics from third-parties for advertising, analytics services (source)
recs: To control ads on Instagram, you need to go to Facebook. There it’s possible to change preference settings, which will apply to Instagram as well as Facebook

risks: Even if you are not an active user, Instagram still collects behavioural data through cookies, analytics from third-parties for advertising, analytics services. For example, what type of stories you are not interested in, how much time you spend on a story before wiping it away (source)
recs: To control ads on Instagram, you need to go to Facebook. There it’s possible to change preference settings, which will apply to Instagram as well as Facebook

story: You decide to take a picture of your outfit of the day.
Do you post it on Instagram?

risks: Your photos can be used by anyone without permission (source)
The new DM feature alerts real-timeily others to exactly what you’re doing on the app and when you’re doing it (source)
recs: Making your post private
Don’t post sensitive or copyrighted photos on Instagram. If you need to post copyrighted photos for advertisement, remember to leverage watermark and other legal preventions

risks: Not Applicable
recs: Not Applicable

story: You suddenly remember that you need to buy a textbook for one of your courses.
Do you buy it on Amazon or from a local bookstore?

risks: Kindle collects your geolocation data (source)
Kindle can access other social media accounts and if you use it for Kindle login (source)
Kindle collects behavioural data through cookies, analytics from third-parties for advertising, analytics services (e.g. page flip using tap or wipe) (source)
recs: Clear Amazon tracking cookies
Disable personal data collected by the OS of the device for marketing and product improvement purpose
Request Amazon to delete existing data it has recorded

risks: The bookstore may require you to sign up for its email marketing program. This often means that your personal information may be collected (e.g. name, phone number, email, age, etc.), and thus increases the risk for your data to be compromised
recs: Do not sign up for the email marketing program if you feel like there is a potential for your personal information to be compromised

story: You are on the payment page.
Are you paying with cash or a credit card?

risks: Payment card and information related to the purchase will be shared with the retailer and the financial institution that issued the card (source)
The financial institution and the payment card network operator receive information about where and when you shopped and how much you spent (source)
Payment terminals can also be built to feed into a retailer’s CRM database or external parties so that a retailer can track your purchases and tie those to other information about you (source)
Credit card information compromisation, unauthorized charges, identity theft (source)
recs: Keep your cards in a safe place, don't lend them to anyone, and cover up when you enter your password in a local setting
For online payment, make sure that the transaction is secure and do not to save your credit card information
Turn of tracking cookies, as some cookies track where you spend, how much you spend, and what you buy
Contact your credit card company immediately when you find fraudulent charges

risks: Cash is usually the safest way for payment when it comes to privacy issues!
recs: Not Applicable

story: After a long day you are finally home. You are starving and decide to order some pizza delivery (Pepperoni, yum!) online.
Do you order pizza delivery on UberEats or call the pizza place to order and pick up in person?

risks: UberEats collects behavioural data through cookies to analyze your food preferences and UberEats’ ad partners may send you emails for targeted advertising. (source)
UberEats also collects your search and order histories on the site, which can be used to analyze your food preferences and used by its ad partners for targeted advertising. (source)

Your personal and demographic information, such as your email, phone number, and even gender. UberEats specifically stated that "[they] may also infer demographic data from other data collected from users. For example, where necessary to enable features that allow women to provide or receive services from other women, we may infer gender using their first name. In such cases, we enable users to change their gender if necessary via in-app settings." (source)
UberEats’ user data has been leaked on the dark web before (source)
recs: Use a designated email for Uber Eats such that your personal and demographic information become more difficult to be linked to other data you share online.
Use strong passwords. (instructions)

options.optionText: Call the pizza place and pick up in person
risks: Your phone number will be shared with the pizza place employees and may be leaked to spammers due to lack of protection. (source)
Some cities (e.g., New Orleans) have installed surveillance cameras with AI technology, which can log people’s locations in real-time. (source)
recs: You can use Skype or other Internet Phone Calls Apps to make orders such that your phone number will not be leaked. (instructions)
Vote against mass surveillance policies and laws.

story: After a delicious meal, you sit down in front of your computer and decide to play an online video game with your friends.
What software do you use to voice chat with them while playing the game?

risks: Discord will collect your IP address, which can give away your approximate location. (source)
Discord will record all your text messages and images you sent on the platform. (source)
Discord will collect the unique ID of the device you use to access the platform. (source)
Discord may share aggregated or non-personally identifiable information with its partners or others for business purposes. (source)
recs: Do not disclose your personal information in text chats on Discord.
Avoid using Discord if you are not willing to have your text conversations, location, or device ID recorded.

risks: Your phone number will be shared with Signal. However, according to Signal, your phone number will not be used to link to you whatsoever. Signal also claims that "[it] does not sell, rent or monetize your personal data or content in any way – ever." (source)
recs: Donate to Signal, it is a non-profit software and relies on donations to keep itself in business. (instructions)

story: After losing at the online game for 2 hours straight, you decide to rage quit and watch a movie instead. You heard your favorite director’s latest movie has just been released, but it's still only released in theatres.
Do you watch another movie on Netflix or watch your favorite director’s latest movie on an illegal streaming website?

risks: Netflix collects your billing information, including your address and legal name. (source)

Netflix records your IP addresses, which can give away your approximate locations. Netflix also collects behavioural data through cookies, analytics from third-parties for advertising, analytics services. (source)
Netflix records your watch history and your likes and dislikes, which will be used to analyze your preferences in shows. (source)
Although you may delete your viewing history to stop Netflix from making recommendations to you using those viewing history, it may not be removed from Netflix’s server. (source)
Netflix collects the unique ID of the device you use to access the platform. (source)
recs: Do not use Netflix if you do not wish to have your show preferences recorded.
Contact your credit card company immediately when you find fraudulent charges.
Use strong passwords. (instructions)

risks: Illegal streaming websites have access to your IP address when you try to access them, which gives out your approximate location, and have access to information about your browser, your operating-system, such as their versions. (source)
Illegal streaming websites may collect behavioural data through cookies, analytics from third-parties for advertising, analytics services. (source)
Due to lack of funding and regulations, illegal streaming websites have little incentives to protect users’ data from being hacked (source).
In fact, illegal streaming websites could be intentionally exposing your computer to the intrusion of malware or cryptomining software. (source)

Some illegal streaming websites charge or require registration to get rid of advertisements, which means that they will collect your billing information, including your home address, credit card information, and legal name. (source)
recs: Avoid illegal streaming sites whenever possible to avoid your computer being hacked and your online activities being leaked.
Never make transactions on illegal streaming websites. It will put your billing information and your personal information in significant danger.
